results.title: An Interview with James Ross Irvine
results.brief_description: James Ross Irvine and his brother were both involved in significant battles in Papua New Guinea in World War II. With a stoic sensibility and grim humour, Irvine relates the story of the last time he saw his brother before he was killed in battle.
results.description: James Ross Irvine and his brother were both involved in significant battles in Papua New Guinea in World War II. With a stoic sensibility and grim humour, Irvine relates the story of the last time he saw his brother before he was killed in battle.

results.title: An Interview with Jack Jones
results.brief_description: Born in Ascot Vale, Jack Jones was only fifteen when Menzies declared war so he had to wait till 1942 before he could sign up. Put through extensive training he was posted in New Guinea and, later, Bougainville, where they had to wait for four months after the war ended to be brought home. While some of his colleagues went ‘troppo’, Jones coped by seeing his time in the war as a job.

results.title: An Interview with Harry Barkla
results.brief_description: Harry Barkla was part of the 39th Battalion, made up mostly of Chocolate (Chocco) soldiers. They were called this because it was thought that they would melt in the sun, that they wouldn’t know how to fight. In Kokoda, they soon proved themselves and Harry talks about some of the horrific experiences he went through that were typical of this war. These are some of his memories that he has tried to forget but never can. Even if you didn’t know someone’s name in the 39th Battalion, you still called them mate and you never forget your mates.

results.title: An Interview with Harold Brown
results.brief_description: Harold Brown reflects fondly on his time in the army. Joining the artillery division in 1942, he was posted to Bougainville, where disease was more of a threat to the soldiers than the Japanese. Despite longing to be back home with his newborn son, Brown could not have wished to be with a better crew.

results.title: An Interview with Glenn James
results.brief_description: When Glenn James’ fellow soldiers returned from service in Vietnam, they told him they finally understood what it was like to be Indigenous - you get treated like rubbish. Vietnam soldiers were brought home under the cover of night and at best ignored. For James, this was nothing new. As he talks about the plight of others that he has committed his life to helping, James provides some insight into an indomitable spirit, and how he has focused his energy into creating positive change for others.

results.title: An Interview with Gillian Armstrong
results.brief_description:
Award-winning Australian film and documentary director Gillian Armstrong’s film career spans over 40 years locally and internationally.

Here she shares her discovery of Orry-Kelly and the incredibly fortunate set of events that uncovered his memoir and his box of memorabilia including his three Oscars.

The release of Armstrong’s 2015 feature-length documentary on the life and work of renowned costume designer Orry-Kelly, ‘Women He’s Undressed’, coincided with ACMI’s exhibition ‘Orry-Kelly: Dressing Hollywood’.

results.title: An Interview with George Derham
results.creator_credit: George Derham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: George Derham was called up to serve for Australia on the 4/4/44. He joined the Australian Navy and recalls his time there, of fitting in and standing out. Collecting Australian prisoners of war in Japan, two images affected Derham greatly - that of Tokyo after the extensive firebombing by the US, and the emaciated state of the prisoners of war. Despite this, Derham sees military life as a valuable part of his development and works hard to assist returned soldiers and their families.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Derham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

Despite this, Derham sees military life as a valuable part of his development and works hard to assist returned soldiers and their families.

Collecting Australian prisoners of war in Japan, two images affected Derham greatly - that of Tokyo after the extensive firebombing by the US, and the emaciated state of the prisoners of war. Despite this, Derham sees military life as a valuable part of his development and works hard to assist returned soldiers and their families.

results.title: An Interview with Frank Cox
results.brief_description: Frank Cox signed up to joined the army to see what they had in store for him. He started work as a dispatch rider in Palestine and finished up in the Suez Canal as part of his training. After serving in Tobruk and Greece, Cox became a prisoner of war and has borne witness to the suffering of his colleagues.

results.title: An Interview with Evelyn Warner
results.brief_description: Evelyn Warner was in London when World War II was declared. As a very young cadet, Warner cycled around the countryside delivering messages. Then one day she had an encounter with a ‘doddlebug’, an unmanned plane designed to crash and burn, that left her red-faced.
